title: A moment of reflection: The Warwick rework was examplary
body: And might I add, one of the few reworks everyone didn't lose their shit over. They kept the beginner jungler element, while keeping his style as jungler. He feels really smooth to play and has very clear strengths and weaknesses. I can say (at least to me), this rework was absolutely perfect.

replies.body: The two things keeping his rework from being perfect are the wonky Q interaction and the fact that you can literally pass overtop of an enemy champ with his ult and not have it "hit" the enemy champ.  The hitbox for his ult is just way too narrow.

Yeah the Q can feel a bit wonkey, but I appreciate that they at least tried to do something different with it. And on his ult, I guess people just didn't want targeted suppression. Can't blame them, but I do agree with you.

I love his Q, it is just very hard to utilize it correctly because of how it works.  If it actually worked like every time I press it and hold it, it would be perfect.  But it doesn't :(  But I love the thought with it.

And don't take my complaints as a knock against the rework.  I had about 125k mastery points on WW pre-rework, and another 125k mastery points post-rework, and I love the rework!  Not that I didn't like WW pre-rework, he just feels like he offers a lot more now, especially early.  Like I said, though, there are two issues I have with his abilities which would really fix him if they worked right.

While I personally did like to various degrees all of the major reworks, I do admt that warwick exceded in 3 aspects more so than the others:

1.-They actually updated his art rather than just build something entirely different. While reworks like Sion, Galio and Yorick are cool looking, they did not take enough from the previous models to look familiar. Yes, of course you should change them, but not to the extent that they are unrecognizable. Poppy and Warwik are both good examples of what to do right in this department.

2.-The gameplay is fun while keeping warwick's gameplay theme familiar. It is expected that with updates a champions kit will change, but keeping it thematic to the character while also conserving what worked on the previous one is when a gameplay update succeds. Gangplank and Warwick are great examples of what to do right. Yorick and Galio are ok given how unplayable their older kits were, but maybe could have had improvements. Fiora and Sion are examples of how to create basically a new champion that is only losely related to an older one

3.-Warwicks gameplay is what people imagined they were doing while playing old warwick, only now its true. The way the visual thematics tie in to gameplay was really good

On top of keeping his beginner friendly nature, they didn't totally screw it up like Garen's in that they managed to keep a low skill floor while dramatically increasing his skill cap. I hadn't played Warwick regularly in years before the rework came out, but now I feel like actually putting in time on him I can make the kind of advancement in technique that other much more complicated champs have. It's not just skill shots either, it's decision making, strategy, build style, and a lot more macro play in team fights, on top of all the little bits of finesse in how you use your QWER.

Still think Sion's is the best overall, mainly because of WW's janky ult hit box (I swear the collision detection is broken on that thing, you shouldn't be able to miss point blank into 5 champs)

i dislike it for one thing, they made him into the biggest examples of "drain tank" i've ever seen, his lifesteal without any actual damage items is one of the stupidest thing's i've seen, and yet they gut swain and vlad for being even close to becoming drain tanks

WW's healing isn't tied to his damage which is why isn't busted like how Swain and Vlad can become.  WW can still heal even if he can barely scratch someone, but doesn't heal more if he can rip their face off.  That was the problem Riot had with Swain and Vlad, that the stronger they are in a game the harder it is for them to be shutdown and the weaker they are the harder it is for them to be useful.

Drain tanking being attached to damage makes champs very difficult to balance because hitting the sweet spot between them taking over and sucking completely is hard to hit and keep them in.
